headline: Roasted Chicken with Risotto and Caramelized Onions
description: This chicken risotto recipe features creamy Arborio rice cooked in white wine and broth, mixed with tender, roasted chicken and caramelized onions.

video.description: This rich risotto with juicy roasted chicken and caramelized onions is perfect for a fancy dinner or just to treat yourself!
video.name: Roasted Chicken with Risotto and Caramelized Onions

name: Roasted Chicken with Risotto and Caramelized Onions
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons chopped fresh thyme for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Saut√© onion in hot oil until dark golden brown, 15 to 20 minutes.
Remove from heat and stir in balsamic vinegar; set aside.
Heat remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Cook and stir rice in hot oil for 2 minutes.
Pour in wine while stirring. Reduce heat to medium-low.
Pour in 1 cup hot broth; cook and stir until broth is absorbed.
While stirring constantly, continue adding remaining broth, 1 cup at a time, until all broth is absorbed and rice is tender yet firm to the bite, about 20 minutes.
Stir in reserved onion mixture until heated through. Remove from heat.
Stir in chicken and butter; season with salt and pepper. Garnish each serving with thyme.

review.reviewBody: Note that I made this from the printed recipe in the Aug/Sept 2022 Allrecipes magazine. It is slightly different from the on- line recipe. I made it as printed. We really enjoyed this recipe. I did use a rotisserie chicken since I had some already chopped up. I had bought 2 at Costco, stripped them, chopped the meat, and then frozen the chopped meat. I used all 7 cups of the broth but it was more like 30 minutes for it to absorb. The printed version called for 2-1/2 cups of onions, which is more like 2 onions rather than the 1 onion called for on-line. I think it definitely needs the 2-1/2 cups. The 1/4 c. balsamic and 1/4 c. wine were just right- not too overpowering. Fresh thyme from my garden was perfect. This is simple to make, but like any risotto takes a little time. I prepped the onion chicken mix earlier in the day so the final prep was easy. Printed version called for carmelizing the onions for 18-20 min. rather than 15. Next time I would add garlic. My husband said he will gladly eat the left-overs tomorrow.
the recipe was amazing. i saw some of the other comments saying the balsamic was too strong of a flavour but i used a higher quality balsamic and found it perfect and added lots of flavour

Very tasty but the process is a bit off. As others have said, it takes much longer to properly cook the onions, and it takes even longer to cook the risotto. The rice should be creamy, not al dente. I used half as much balsamic vinegar (2 tbsp) and rotisserie chicken. I never needed to add additional salt even though I used low-sodium broth, and the lemon thyme I had on hand added an AMAZING accent flavor.

this was pretty good but I thought it had much to strong a balsamic vinegar taste. I added some parmesan cheese and a dash of cream because I thought it lacked the creaminess that risotto is known for. i also made it in the pressure cooker. learn how to make any risotto recipe in the pressure cooker by reading the cook's notes from the recipe on this site called saffron risotto in the pressure cooker. BTW, that recipe is awesome please go give it a try and a good review!
Delicious!! Made as written except I forgot the butter and at the end. Still a family win!!

This was just OK. One onion was not enough onion for that much rice. I added few mushrooms. It was just too bland, maybe if it had some asparagus or broccoli. I would not make this again as it is written.

Great dish for balsamic lovers which my husband and I are. I always fear risotto but this recipe is a reminder it‚Äôs not hard, just takes a little patience (which I lack.). I took advice from another comment and added sun dried tomatoes and artichokes. Fun meal for a little change!

Lunch Bag Letdown. I cooked it as described. The risotto was done perfectly as were the onions. I even added 1/4 cup of grated Parmesan to add flavour. It didn't work. Lovely textures but brand flavour. 
This will neither offend or impress anyone. 
Skip it.
Very good
Loved it! I saut√©ed minced garlic and shallot before adding rice. Also added a splash of Marsala and pinch of brown sugar to the onions. Helped with the feeling the balsamic being too overpowering.

DELICIOUS! So happy to find a tasty recipe that uses the Costco chicken we never seem to finish. I added 2 cloves garlic, used 6 cups vs 7 (because that's the box size I had and others said it would work), and cut balsamic vinegar in half. I probably would have enjoyed the 1/4 cup of vinegar, but my hubby ins't as big on vinegar flavoring. He had 2 huge servings of this and requested we have it more often. Highly recommend!
Too much balsamic vinegar. I¬¥d cute that down by 1/2 or 3/4.
I cut the recipe in half and used chicken concentrate in place of broth. I was dissatisfied by the consistency of the risotto. I think I would have done better with a full 4 cups of stock.
I followed the recipe exactly the first time and thought it was too much vinegar and where was the cheese 2nd time reduced the vinegar to a tablespoon and added oregano, garlic and Parm. Now love it
I tripled the onions and added mushrooms. It was delicious.
Tasted like another. Very yummy. My first time making Risotto and will not be the last.

OMG! Magnificent! This is, hands down, the best chicken dish I've ever made, and the whole family loved it! My changes were slight and not by choice. Circumstances dictated that my onions were caramelized and chicken breasts were roasted and shredded a day ahead. However, I had to make some fresh onions the next night, as my husband had to have some of the first batch. The third change was that I only had 3 cans of chicken broth, so just shy of 6 cups, but upped the wine to 1/2 c. or so. Whether any of that made any real difference, I can't say. But the result didn't lie! It was nice to have those ready ahead, though. On dinner night, I basically just sipped wine while pouring and stirring broth. That's relaxing dinner prep!
It was okay but tasty. I don't really have anything to compare it to. I've never made or eaten risotto before.

Great recipe! I only used 5 1/2 cups of stock, 7 cups would have been soupy. To those who complained about it being gooey, risotto is a moist dish, not dry like steamed or boiled rice. It did take a bit longer to cook, closer to 30 minutes but a good risotto can‚Äôt be rushed. Also your stock should be kept at a simmer while you use it. As for the complaints about the balsamic, a good balsamic doesn‚Äôt taste strongly of vinegar, it‚Äôs sweeter and more like a good wine so we enjoyed the tang it added to the dish.

This was very good. I will make it again the only change I might make would be using half of the balsamic vinegar just to have a more subtle flavor. As for everything else, this is the perfect recipe to maximize consumption of leftovers to prevent food waste. Just with that, I have plenty a powerful reasons to make this again and again. I only had at the moment dried thyme, so I used 1 tsp and it was perfect with a bit more of an earthy flavor, just as good!

@Linda B. All risottos are cooked to al dente. Have made many a risotto and generally basic risotto takes only 20 minutes to make. However, if you are making anything beyond basic, it will take longer. I only use arborio rice (the easiest to find in the U.S., Italian short rice) when making my risottos, and it is the slow release of starch from the rice and the addition of butter at the end of cooking, which makes your risotto creamy. However, if you cook beyond the point of al dente, you will have a gooey feel in your mouth. It is all about the heat setting and, of course, ensuring proper and complete mise en place!

I'm happy it came up in my IG feed. I just bought a roasted chicken and wasn't in the mood for soup. It took longer than 20 minutes to cook the rice. I added garlic, mushrooms, and roasted vegetables. It's a very basic recipe.

It's not a pretty meal so no picture.

Tasty but takes way longer than the 45 minutes, closer to 1.5 hours. Which sucks when you have hungry kids and a busy night. I added a little less than a 1/4 cup balsamic because of kids tastebuds. Turned out to be perfect balance. One issue I have, the risotto takes so long that the chicken and onions are cold by the time the risotto is done.

I added mushrooms and garlic to the onions. Otherwise I followed the recipe and it was wonderful! 7/8 of the adults who ate loved it. The one said he liked it but wasn‚Äôt as excited about it as the rest. The decision is that we should put it in the rotation!

I love risotto and I make a few different kinds fairly regularly. I‚Äôm surprised the reviews are so positive. I thought this recipe was overpowering in flavour (I only used quality ingredients, including the balsamic), but it really has a strange, unpleasant taste and texture for me. I will not be making this again.
Delicious and simple to make. Substituted white wine vinegar for the white wine. Gave a perfect tartness

This sounded delicious, but we did not like it. I'm not sure if it was the balsamic or the thyme but the taste was just off to me. I'm so bummed too! I make many risotto recipes so I'm confident I made it correctly.
Excellent

This was outstanding, Michele! My guy and I both give it 5 stars and it's definitely going into the rotation. We didn't think there was too much vinegar at all. We added mushrooms because we love them (though it would have been great without them, too) and I was surprised that we only needed 5 cups of broth. Thank you for the wonderful recipe!
I added spinach, mushrooms and 3 tablespoons parmesean cheese. This was my family's favorite risotto.
I used my own chicken which I did with some garlic and I also added 8oz of portabella mushrooms which I did on the side with butter and added with the chicken. Awesome!
This is the only risotto I make or will make, love it.

I followed the advice of another reviewer and increased the onions to 3, added 2 cloves of garlic, reduced the balsamic by a lot to 1 tablespoon, and I definitely added parmesan. The risotto was delicious. Used chicken tenderloins, arborio rice (the rice is important, it absorbs a LOT of fluid and makes a very creamy-textured sauce at the end.) and definitely added parmesan on top. So good. Will make again, even though it's a time-consuming recipe!

I must have done something wrong because this was gooey, and had only the vinegar taste despite adding lots of spices and my own just made homemade chicken broth from a fried turkey remains and wasted the leftover chicken-- still did not help. I know my spouse won't eat this ....

LOVE this dish! Going into my regular rotation. Took about 40 minutes to prepare. I had some left over shredded roasted chicken which I just added as directed. Next time I will chop it up before adding it. Agree with other reviews. Next time I will use 2 onions. I saut√©ed one onion with garlic and used only 1 tablespoon of balsamic. I never made risotto before but I followed the directions and it turned out great. I heated up 5 cups of chicken bone broth and slowly added it to the rice. The trick is frequent stirring and adding only 1 cup or 1 ladle at a time. It took me about 25 minutes or so before the rice was done. I normally used dried herbs and I am glad I bought fresh thyme for presentation purposes. I also saut√©ed some mushrooms on the side and added this at the end (kids don‚Äôt like them but hubby and I do!). I topped it with shaved Parmesan and thyme. Perfect dish for left over chicken!

Made this exactly as written except for the fresh thyme (didn‚Äôt have). My picky kids loved it. Agree with a couple of reviewers that it takes longer than 20 minutes for the risotto to absorb all of the liquid, but worth the wait. I‚Äôll also say that it is very filling so there was a lot left over.

So delicious!!! 
We have to watch our calories and sugar intake so I substituted brown rice.
Very good!!!! Made as directed but also added mushrooms and asparagus that I cooked in butter for 10 minutes!!!! Will definitely make again!
Excellent recipe, omitted the chicken even then it turned out great.
I did use half the balsamic as I was afraid to use more. It was quite good.
Like others have said, less vinegar and add some mushrooms. I used red onions. I also added some saffron to the broth and a little to the completed risotto for an authentic risotto taste.
Will make it again. Added sliced tomatoes on top for colour and some chopped parsley. Very tasty.

I left out the balsamic vinegar and this was very tasty. As other reviewers suggested, I added mushrooms and more onions. I also substituted 1/2 c. of broth for white wine. I haven't made risotto before and although it took me considerably longer than stated (40 minutes), it was pretty easy.

I just cooked up a couple of chicken breasts rather than using a rotisserie chicken. Pretty well followed the recipe but probably added more carmarelized onions than called as I love them and I will make a whole batch of the onions in my slow cooker and freeze in packagesl. Very tasty recipe.

Great recipe. Risotto turned out creamy and tasted good/salty enough with 3.5 cups of chicken broth. 

Next time, I'll probably cut the balsamic vinegar to half the portion as well. It was a bit too sour for us with the proposed portion. 

It is possible to reduce cooking time by cooking the rice and the onions at the same.

Great recipe. Risotto turned out creamy and tasted good/salty enough with 3.5 cups of chicken broth. 

Next time, I'll probably cut the balsamic vinegar to half the portion as well. It was a bit too sour for us with the proposed portion. 

It is possible to reduce cooking time by cooking the rice and the onions at the same.

I made this tonight and it IS quite tasty. It does take longer than 20 min for the rice to absorb all of the liquid. I also added a bit of garlic to the onion/balsamic vinegar base mixture. My husband thought the balsamic flavor was a bit too strong. I will cut back a bit on the vinegar next time. But overall, very good recipe!
I love a good risotto! This is lovely with the carmelized onions!

I made a roast chicken for dinner one night, then used the leftover chicken for this dish the next day. I followed the recipe, but added mushrooms (baby portabello) and diced sauteed garlic--just threw them in the empty pan after the onions were done cooking and left it on medium low, stirring occasionally. About halfway through cooking the risotto, I added the cooked chicken to the mushrooms and garlic to warm it up. I also made 2 cups of rice instead of 1.5, to help balance all the extra ingredients. My whole family loved it and asked me to make it again! It has wonderful warm, complex flavors and is easy to make, although you are at the stove the whole time.

Going on our favorites list for sure.

First time making risotto and the reviews and instructions were very helpful. I cut down the amount of balsamic as noted in the comments and added garlic to the onions. Consistency was perfect but the flavor is pretty bland unless there's a big chunk of the carmelized onions. If I make it again I will up the onions, garlic, salt, pepper and butter and see if that helps.
This was delicious but I did cut the balsamic vinegar in half. I'll definitely make it again
I used half the amount of balsamic vinegar, based on previous review, glad I did, and added some veggies towards the end. I love it but not the 6 & 8 yr old.

We're risotto aficionados and thoroughly enjoyed this dish. Don't be alarmed by the nay sayers. The onions and balsamic vinegar are delicious in the rice (I drained the excess vinegar before adding the onions to the dish). I added some saut√©ed mushrooms and some peas to make it a one dish meal. We're looking forward to using the left overs for crispy risotto cakes!

Wonderful flavor mixes; from the balsamic vinegar to the carmelized onions and thyme. We loved it. I did purchase a small 28oz rotisserie chicken that was on sale so we probably had twice as much chicken,and I only used about 5 1/2 cups of broth, but other than that I did not change anything else. My husband called it the best in comfort food. Thanks for a wonderful recipe!!

Not sure if I did something wrong or the balsamic vinegar I used but the balsamic just over powered the dish. I did everything as the recipe stated except added mushrooms. It smelled great and looked great but the vinegar was just over powering. I will try again and use less balsamic next time. I read reviews before I made it and no one mentioned it so I'm thinking it may have been something I did.

I used the crock pot caramelized onion recipe for this & then followed the rest of recipe as stated except for adding sun dried tomatoes. It was delicious! Will definitely make again. Might add saut√©ed mushrooms also next time. Easy - once you have made the crock pot onions - and delicious.

I tried this recipe as written. However I like mine 10 star more. I use dry vermouth instead of wine matter of choice. I caramelize the onions remove set aside, in same skillet add 1-2 Tbsps. butter if available fresh chopped shitake, baby portabellas, oyster mushrooms and crimini, a combination of mushrooms is best, saut√© when soft and cooked to liking, combine with the caramelized onion reserve for later. There should be enough butter/olive oil no need to add additional, didn't care for the balsamic vinegar so I omitted it. Stir in rice as instructed then add vermouth or white wine, until absorbed then begin adding broth 1 cup at a time until your risotto is done to your liking. It always amazes me how anyone can cook risotto in 20 minutes mine is always at least 30-45 minutes. You need to stay with this adding more broth as it absorbs. When done add the mushroom/onions stir in salt and pepper to taste. I also use fresh grated parmesan and I prefer parsley to thyme. I know I completely changed this up just though I would share my version
I added mushrooms, cooked chicken, and peas to make it more of an entr√©e. It was delicious!! I love the onion, mushroom, and balsamic vinegar combo!

I don't know why we give 5 stars to recipes that we've altered somehow, but here I go, doing just that. I took to heart other reviewers thoughts about the balsamic being too much and halved it to only 2 tbs, instead of the 1/4c it calls for. Also, I used the stock from the previous night's roasted chicken, and added some chicken bouillon to it for flavor. In addition, I probably used closer to 3 cups of chicken, as it's what I had leftover. The result? Oh.em.gee. It was wonderful! I've never made a rissotto before, and I'm feeling pretty impressed with myself over it. One note: I did make sure the wine AND the stock were fairly hot when I added it to the rice mix, and it took far longer than 20 minutes for it all to absorb--"20 minutes" was much more like "one hour". But no matter--I'll be making it again, for sure!
Horrible recipe. BV and rice are NOT a good combination. One thing I got out of it is that thyme encrusted chicken is delicious, so at least that part will be used again.

Delicious!! Yes, Risotto takes a while to cook, but it is worth the effort. I added some saut√©ed mushrooms before adding the rice. I also halved the balsamic since my Wife isn't a big fan. She really liked it though. The balsamic adds a nice sweetness along with the caramelized onions. Definitely a keeper!

I made this last night for the family and it was super tasty! I used my own chicken breasts that I seasoned, pan seared in olive oil and then finished in oven while I got the onions going. I took others advice about cutting back on the balsamic and only used about 1 1/2 TBSP. My risotto only needed about 5 cups of broth. I will definitely be making this on a regular basis.

I've been using this recipe for a while and keep forgetting to review it! We LOVE this recipe, when I have time to make it. I'd always been a little scared of making risotto, but this recipe was well written. The balsamic onions add a nice sweetness and tang to the overall creamy dish, which is much needed. Without them, I could see this being way too heavy. Good balance, good texture. This is one of the few recipes I follow exactly every time! I have substituted basil for thyme depending on what I have on hand and it works very well, too.
excellent! i added mushrooms too.. It takes way LONGER than 45 minutes,, more like 80 minutes to prepare. If you have the time it's worth it :)

I guess it was my fault that the dish tasted like Balsamic Vinegar overload. When I added the vinegar to the onions I didn't cook it down, I just stirred it in. The flavor of vinegar was overwhelmingt. Added more onion and that didn't help. This recipe also makes a huge amount. I will make it again without so much Balsamic Vinegar

Delicious.

Here's how to roast the chicken (I used three smaller boneless/skinless breasts): Just pour a small amount of olive oil (other oil probably would work) in a casserole dish. Take the breasts and put them in the casserole dish and then turn them over so they have a thin coating of oil on both sides. Then just put a little salt and pepper and put in the oven for 25 minutes at 350 degrees if small breasts or 30 minutes at 350 if larger. Alow breasts to rest about ten minutes and then cut into small strips or cubes. And that's it.

You can actually cook the onions and the risotto at the same time. So I had the onions carmelizing on one burner, the risotto simmering on a second one and then the chicken stock/broth simmering on the third so it was hot to stir in. 

Once done, I did mix in a little parmesan cheese in addition to the butter is calls for.

Served with a ceasar salad. Really, really good. I'll definitely make it again. Leftovers were delicious too.

Thanks for the recipe. It's a keeper.
This is a wonderful recipe!!! The onions and balsamic really make this rich. I will make this again!!
Really easy recipe and tastes delicious! First time making risotto and turned out great. I also added field mushrooms that I fried off in garlic and topped it with grated parmesan as well, yum!
Thought this was very good, although the kids thought a little less wine.

This was very good, but certainly takes longer than 45 minutes! Make sure you use a good balsamic to really maximize the flavor. The chicken needs to be seasoned or it will be very bland against the rice. We sauteed small cubes with some salt, pepper, garlic powder, and thyme and that went very well with the other flavors already in the dish. Rice definitely takes longer than 20 minutes to absorb- plan on a good 45 for a real slow-cooked risotto. We also added a couple of cloves of pressed garlic to the onion mixture and chopped the onions very small so as not to have too much crunch in the texture of the rice, but that's just a matter of preference. Overall, nice flavors- just takes a while!

After reading several of the reviews I changed a few things as well. I added Mushrooms and shrimp to the onion mixture. I also sauteed them in butter and Garlic instead of the oil. with the Rice it took a little longer than the 20mins. I also cut up chicken breast and cooked it with my own seasoning. I added the needed amount of butter to the risotto and the chicken to the onion mixture and then combined everything together. IT was so Good! all my kids and my Husband just loved it! this is one meal I will make often!

This was decent. I have never had risotto before so I wasn't sure what to expect. I did add mushrooms and a bit of garlic as other reviewers suggested. I also cooked two chicken breasts on my Foreman grill as another review suggested and I seasoned the chicken with garlic powder and seasoning salt. My husband and 3 year old did not care for it, but my 6 year old liked it. I would have to agree that the balsamic is a bit on the strong side and can definitely be reduced. The cooking time was also off as this did take about 45 minutes for the rice to absorb the fluid. I probably won't make this version again, but I am opening to trying different versions.
Wonderful recipe. I do suggest cutting the balsamic in half and adding sauted mushrooms and parmesean cheese (1/2 C) at the end. I have made this a half a dozen times and always get raves!

This was really good, but I felt like it was missing something. Maybe roasted tomatoes or zucchini? I'm still not sure. Regardless, I'm sure I'll make this again, minus the balsamic vinegar (I didn't think it really meshed with the rest of the recipe).

I'll give this 5 stars BUT I did only put 1 tablespoon of balsamic in. Any more would have been overkill. Took about 6 cups of the chicken broth and I added a little parmesan with the butter. Had a really nice flavor!
Balsamic vinegar overpowered the dish. If I try again I'll use less balsamic.

Very good. I have made this several times. I heat the chicken broth in a sauce pan so it is hot when I add it. I also reduce the amount of balsalmic by about 1/2. I have made this w/o chicken or using a store-bought rotisserie chicken. It is very easy to make. There is a lot of stirring involved, but I just get a glass of wine, put on some music, and hang out with my risotto by the stove.

I agree with the other reviews about too much basalmic and I love love love basalmic. It was a bit over powering in this recipe. Also the cook time is off by quite a bit. I've made a lot of risotto and it takes about an hour not 20 minutes. I would not make this again.
The new best thing I cook. I fried the chicken in peanut oil. Add mushrooms to onions. Its weird, I can still taste it after an half hour. Really good.
The balsamic flavor was a bit too much for me. Next time I would cut the balsalmic in half. The title should be Balsamic Chicken with Risotto and Onions because that is the main flavor of the dish.
very tasty - served with parmesan cheese

I finally got around to trying this recipe last night (it's been in my recipe box for almost 8 years), and we were very pleased with it. The only thing I did differently was to use about 1t dried thyme stirred in near the end of cooking, rather than fresh. I did notice that I needed only 5 cups of broth, but would still have the amount called for ready for use. Using a really good balsamic vinegar is important - the best I've found is Kirkland Signature from Costco. This recipe is a definite keeper. Thanks, Michele!

The balsamic vinegar is OVERPOWERING and ruins what could possibly be a good dish. I like balsamic vinegar but this was simply too much. A tablespoon might be okay but I would only add a little at a time tasting it as you go. In any case taste it before you add the chicken as you may want to save your chicken for something edible.
I did not care for this recipe. not worth all the time.

This was awesome! I used pearl rice which is a cheaper similar version of arborio and it worked great. I wound up using about 6 cups of broth. I omitted the thyme just out of preference and topped with cheese and chives instead. The caramelized onions were SOOO good with the balsamic vinegar on them. This definitely does take a lot longer than it states but it's VERY delicious.
Good flavor but arbrio rice is expensive. My first time making risotto and it came out a bit mushy. Also, time estimates are way below actual.

I did not use all of the broth, eliminated the wine and added artichokes. It took more than 20 minutes, but it was delicious,. Next time, I think I might try 1) using low-sodium broth and about 2) 1/2 only half the vinegar.
Wasn't for me.

Incredible! Had this as a side dish without the chicken because we had steak as the main dish. I thought this was the best risotto I have ever made. An a+ from my daughter, too. I was actually afraid of adding the carmelized red onions to her rice but she loved it. When using chicken buillon, make sure to use unsalted butter. Oh and also it wasn't necessary to sprinkle thyme.

Great dish. Tasty and easy to adjust to suit your tastes and needs. You can put anything you want with the rice base. It's not hard to make, but does take time. The 20 minutes to stated for broth to be absorbed took nearly an hour. Heating the broth before adding (and re-heating between pours) helps the absorption speed a bit. If you have the time, it's worth it. -- I have to add that the thyme is really a great garnish for this!

The first few bites were great, but by the time I got to the middle of my portion it was boring. It makes for nothing but edible, but not tasty, leftovers. Leftovers sustain us. I enjoyed the onions and balsamic together.

This was delicious, and easy. I love risotto anyway I can get it and this was a nice addition. The only thing I did different was when I was done cooking the onion I deglazed the pan with white wine and cooked the chicken in it and sliced it into small pieces and it was really good cause all I had was boneless on hand. Excellent dish Michele

It was ok. I didn't have Risotto, and our store didn't carry it so I had to substitute it with brown rice. It had great flavor, I added some garlic to the rice while it was cooking just because every review said it need some help on flavor. I also did what others did with cutting down on the balsamic vinegar, I just sprinkled a little on the onions and mushrooms (also what reviews advised) and tossed. I liked it, but it wasn't like awesome or anything. Nothing to rave too much about, but was good enough to eat and not have to use the backup pizza for (haha).
Easy and tasty! Took a while to cook the risotto but it was worth every bite :)

This was really good and my first time making risotto which I was super nervous about but it was perfect. I thought the balsamic was a bit overpowering so the next time I make it I will use a little less than what the recipe calls for.
Made as it was printed and it was WAY too much balsamic if you ask me. The risotto came out perfect - have the sore shoulder to prove it!

We followed the recipe pretty close and felt like it was good but needed something. Like possibly bacon...ha. I know, bacon makes ANYTHING good. But for all the time it took (a good hour and a half) we didn't feel it was worth the time. Couple things we would change: add into the actual recipe part a step to heat the broth before adding because we totally forgot to heat it before adding. Not a huge deal but I think it would have cooked much faster. Also we felt 2 Tbsp thyme was too much. It was definitely creamy though and we just cooked the chicken in the same pan after the onion mixture so maybe if we had gotten a rotisserie it would have added to the overall flavor.
The risotto was good, but it turned out very very sweet (and I love balsamic) so it was hard to eat more than a few bites of it. Also, I added mushrooms which I would completely recommend.

Delicious! I left out the butter ... mostly because I forgot.. but I don't think it needed it anyway - if you cook it right, it will be creamy already. I might want more onion next time and will probably add some veggies like asparagus. Thanks!

item.name: Roasted Chicken with Risotto and Caramelized Onions
